title: Malzahar has a 57.79% winrate and 90.65% banrate.
body:
Sorce: http://na.op.gg/champion/malzahar/statistics/jungle

For some reason, that feels like a problem.

Maybe it's the 90% damage reduction that also makes him immune to all CC for a full second that refreshes every 4s in late game (23s-4s scaling).
Maybe it's the fact he has one of the fastest and safest jungle clears with half a dozen Voidlings just about every single camp to tank and clear for him.
Maybe it's the fact he can solo any Dragon or Rift Herald, and Baron by pretty much the time it spawns.
Maybe it's the fact he has 2 of the arguably 3 strongest CCs (Silence + Suppress, Stun being the third). One of them being on an extremely low CD while the other is on a relatively short CD considering it's an ultimate that deals massive % health damage.

But maybe I'm just overthinking things.

Agreed on OP still having a very good, valid point, but going one step further on the CC value scale, he actually has two mid-range CC effects.

EDIT ONE: This is based on implementation within this game currently
EDIT TWO: Added Pacify

Knockup
Stun > Charm = Fear
Silence > Suppress > Taunt > Displacement (push > pull)
Snare > Slow
Pacify > Blind

* **--Tier 0: _"Just Let It Happen"_--** Nothing resists or cancels Knockup, and it's a full disable for the duration, so it's definitely king.
* **--Tier 1: _Full Disable, Engage and Disengage_--**
* Stun is a full disable that is resistible, but it isn't negated when the source unit dies.
* Charm and Fear both are full disables good for engage and disengage, but are innately ally-negatable (they expire almost instantly if the source unit dies). The repositioning effect makes charm a better engage, but fear a better disengage, resulting in them being about the same in over-all power. While Suppress itself is just like Charm and Fear, only without the movement (making it a neutral version of Charm/Fear), the implementation within this game has it combined with a pulling displacement or a self-suppress, making it very definitely a Tier 2 ability.
* **--Tier 2: _Situational Disable or Interrupt_--**
* Silence basically shuts down anything that isn't mindless right-clicking (even ADCs dislike being silenced), making it useful in both engage and disengage
* While the core of Suppress has it in Tier 1, all implementations currently in the game either also suppress yourself (Malzahar, Urgot, Warwick) or combine it with a Pulling Displacement (Skarner, Kench), forcing it to be Tier 2 because its implementation makes it obligate engage.
* Taunt is a full disable, but they autoattack you. Situationally really powerful, but also situationally terrible (taunting the fed ADC when low on HP is never a good idea). You can really only use it to engage, not disengage. It also cancels on the source unit's death
* Displacement is very much like Knockup.... but can be accidentally used to save an enemy or kill an ally as it forces rapid, oft significant movement (unlike charm/fear, which force slowed, minor movement). This makes it significantly more risky than Suppress or Taunt. Also note that a Push Displacement is better than a Pull displacement, as the former can be used both as engage and disengage, while a pull displacement can only disengage in a sacrificial manner.
* **--Tier 3: _Useful Non-Interrupt_--**
* Snare is great for disengage, but is really only for setup / press purposes on engage. It is, however, very powerful against champions that specialize in not holding still (Ahri, Zed, LeBlink, etc) as it blocks a good portion of what they do.
* Slows are like snares in that they function mostly as disengage and setup / press, but unlike snares, it doesn't effect ability based movement, so Ahri, Zed, LeBlink, etc are significantly less hamstrung by it.
* **--Tier 4: _Situational Only_--**
* Pacify actually disables the ability to autoattack, making it stronger than blind, but it has nearly the exact same effect. IIRC the only advantage it really has is Blind's weird interactions with a few on-attack/hit effects, which lets it edge blind out just a little.
* Blind is only useful against autoattackers, and some of them can even mitigate it with abilities. Very situational outside of lane phase, though can win a teamfight if used right, but "oh no, I'm the mage/tank/ad-caster and I'm blind."

Of course, anything Tier 2 or higher (on this scale)  is pretty damn good to have, so...

This tier list is based on universality of disable:
- Fullness of Disable (as in what actions can the champion still do while effected)
- Situational Reliance (as in preference towards engage or disengage)
- Resistability (as in how hard is it to get out of)

Reason being, designing a situation where any one effect is exactly what you need is easy.
Having an effect that is good in every situation is hard.

_**Tier 0 vs Tier 1:**_

Both completely disables all control.
Both are strongly viable for both Engage and Disengage.

Tier 1 may be cancelled by QSS directly
Tier 1 may be cancelled by the Source Unit's death
Tier 1 may be resisted by Tenacity

Tier 0 either ignores QSS or requires additional actions to cancel with QSS
Tier 0 is never cancelled by the Source Unit's death
Tier 0 is never resisted by Tenacity

Knockup is the only CC that matches everything I listed.
Charm has a preference to engage, is cancelled by QSS, is affected by Tenacity, and is cancelled by the Source Unit's death.

_**Tier 1 Internal**_

All three completely disable all control.

All three are viable for both Disengage and Engage, as Charm and Fear lower movement speed.
However, there is preference:
- Engage power as: Charm > Stun > Fear
- Disengage power as: Fear > Stun > Charm
Stun is second best at both, Charm and Fear both take one first and one third. 
Accounting for this, we get Charm = Stun = Fear

Then we look at how you can remove it.
All three are cancelled by QSS
All three are affected by Tenacity
Charm and Fear (NOT Stun) are cancelled if the source unit dies.

This puts Stun > Charm = Fear.
